questions.prompt: What is the primary purpose of a database index?
questions.explanation: Indexes speed up queries by providing quick access paths to data, avoiding full table scans.

options: Physical storage order of table data
questions.explanation: Clustered indexes sort and store table rows in order based on the index key.

questions.prompt: A table can have multiple clustered indexes.
questions.explanation: A table can have only one clustered index since data can only be physically sorted one way.

questions.prompt: What is the main disadvantage of having many indexes on a table?
questions.explanation: Each index must be maintained during write operations, adding overhead.

questions.prompt: An index that contains all columns needed by a query is called a ______ index.
questions.explanation: Covering indexes satisfy queries entirely from the index without accessing the table.

questions.prompt: Why are B-trees ideal for database indexes?
options: They minimize disk I/O with high fanout
questions.explanation: B-trees have high fanout (many children per node), keeping tree height low and reducing disk reads.

questions.prompt: In a B+ tree, where is all data stored?
questions.explanation: B+ trees store all data pointers in leaf nodes; internal nodes contain only keys for navigation.

questions.prompt: B+ tree leaf nodes are linked for efficient range queries.
questions.explanation: B+ tree leaves are linked sequentially, enabling efficient range scans without traversing internal nodes.

questions.prompt: What operation is triggered when a B-tree node becomes full during insertion?
questions.explanation: Node splits divide full nodes and promote the median key to the parent.

questions.prompt: The time complexity for searching in a B-tree with n elements is:
questions.explanation: B-tree search is O(log n) due to the balanced tree structure.
Hash indexes provide O(1) lookup for exact matches but cannot support range queries.

questions.prompt: A composite index on (A, B, C) can efficiently support which query?
questions.explanation: Composite indexes follow leftmost prefixâ€”queries must use leading columns (A, then B, then C).

questions.prompt: A partial index indexes only a subset of rows based on a condition.
questions.explanation: Partial indexes are smaller and more efficient when queries frequently filter on specific conditions.

questions.prompt: Which index type would you choose for full-text search?
questions.explanation: Full-text indexes (GIN in PostgreSQL) support word-based searches with relevance ranking.

questions.prompt: Bitmap indexes are most effective for columns with ______ cardinality.
questions.explanation: Bitmap indexes work well for columns with few distinct values (like status or gender).
